channel.title: Getting to Recovery
channel.description: This series discusses the Thirteen Affirmation Statements of Women for Sobriety, Inc. (www.womenforsobriety.org) and how women can apply these statements to find their own recovery.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Finding life after alcohol using Women for Sobriety, Inc.
channel.itunes:author: M. Broughton Boone
channel.itunes:summary: This series discusses the Thirteen Affirmation Statements of Women for Sobriety, Inc. (www.womenforsobriety.org) and how women can apply these statements to find their own recovery.

item.title: Statement Twelve: Embracing the Competence Within
item.description: This episode discusses Statement Twelve of the Women for Sobriety "New Life" program. This statement says, "I am a competent woman and have much to give life. This is what I am and I shall know it always."
item.dc:creator: M. Broughton Boone
item.itunes:summary: This episode discusses Statement Twelve of the Women for Sobriety "New Life" program. This statement says, "I am a competent woman and have much to give life. This is what I am and I shall know it always."

item.title: Statement Eleven: If Something Can Go Right, It Will
item.description:
In this episode we discuss Statement Eleven of the Women for Sobriety "New Life" program.  This statement reads, Enthusiasm is my daily exercise.  I treasure all moments of my new life.  From the essay:



Opening ourselves to a life of enthusiasm can be as simple as changing one thought; instead of saying, “anything that can go wrong, will”, what would happen if we were to say, “anything that can go right, will?”  Isn’t it easier to show enthusiasm when you believe things will go right than it is when you expect them to go wrong?
item.dc:creator: M. Broughton Boone
item.itunes:summary:
In this episode we discuss Statement Eleven of the Women for Sobriety "New Life" program.  This statement reads, Enthusiasm is my daily exercise.  I treasure all moments of my new life.  From the essay:
Opening ourselves to a life of enthusiasm can be as simple as changing one thought; instead of saying, “anything that can go wrong, will”, what would happen if we were to say, “anything that can go right, will?”  Isn’t it easier to show enthusiasm when you believe things will go right than it is when you expect them to go wrong?

item.title: Statement Ten: Learning to Love the "I"
item.description:
In this episode, we consider Statement 10 of the Women for Sobriety "New Life" program.  This statement reads, "All love given returns.  I will learn to know that others love me."  In addiction, it can be very difficult to grasp the idea of loving and being loved.  Once we become sober, we can struggle with understanding how to love.

From this episode:

We have all had the experience of meeting someone who has an aura of warmth about them.  When we develop our sense of self-love, this is how others will come to see us.  It is this outward expression of our inner love that allows others to truly love us.  When we approach our lives with love for ourselves and, by extension, compassion for others, we draw that positive energy back to us.  We find ourselves with better health, a better emotional state, and more lightness in our approach to life.  When we love ourselves, we can connect with and feel the love of the entire world.
item.dc:creator: M. Broughton Boone
item.itunes:summary: In this episode, we consider Statement 10 of the Women for Sobriety "New Life" program.  This statement reads, "All love given returns.  I will learn to know that others love me."  In addiction, it can be very difficult to grasp the idea of loving and being loved.  Once we become sober, we can struggle with understanding how to love. From this episode: We have all had the experience of meeting someone who has an aura of warmth about them.  When we develop our sense of self-love, this is how others will come to see us.  It is this outward expression of our inner love that allows others to truly love us.  When we approach our lives with love for ourselves and, by extension, compassion for others, we draw that positive energy back to us.  We find ourselves with better health, a better emotional state, and more lightness in our approach to life.  When we love ourselves, we can connect with and feel the love of the entire world.

item.title: Statement Nine: Letting Go of the Past
item.description:
In this episode, we discuss Statement Nine of the WFS "New Life" program.  The past is gone forever.  No long will I be victimized by the past.  I am a new woman.  From this episode:

... we are often reminded by others of our past transgressions when we become sober; it is up to us to learn how to respond to these situations without becoming embroiled in self-doubt and self-hatred, as these are states which frequently lead to relapse.  Statement Nine provides us with a framework for this understanding.  The words are simple, but they resonate very deeply with the essence of what it means to be in recovery.
item.dc:creator: M. Broughton Boone
item.itunes:summary:
In this episode, we discuss Statement Nine of the WFS "New Life" program.  The past is gone forever.  No long will I be victimized by the past.  I am a new woman.  From this episode:
... we are often reminded by others of our past transgressions when we become sober; it is up to us to learn how to respond to these situations without becoming embroiled in self-doubt and self-hatred, as these are states which frequently lead to relapse.  Statement Nine provides us with a framework for this understanding.  The words are simple, but they resonate very deeply with the essence of what it means to be in recovery.

item.title: Statement Eight: Doing the Right Things
item.description: This episode discusses Statement Eight of the Women for Sobriety "New Life" program.  The fundamental object of life is emotional and spiritual growth.  When we find ourselves struggling in sobriety, it is important that we ask the right questions.  Should we ask if we are doing things right, or if we are doing the right things?
item.dc:creator: M. Broughton Boone
item.itunes:summary: This episode discusses Statement Eight of the Women for Sobriety "New Life" program.  The fundamental object of life is emotional and spiritual growth.  When we find ourselves struggling in sobriety, it is important that we ask the right questions.  Should we ask if we are doing things right, or if we are doing the right things?

item.title: Statement Seven: Love Yourself, Change Your World
item.description: This episode discusses Statement Seven of the Women for Sobriety New Life program.
item.dc:creator: M. Broughton Boone
item.itunes:summary: This episode discusses Statement Seven of the Women for Sobriety New Life program.

item.title: Statement Six: Embracing a Life of Greatness
item.description: This episode discusses Statement Six of the Women for Sobriety program, Life can be ordinary or it can be great.  How do we find the greatness already existing in our lives?
item.dc:creator: M. Broughton Boone
item.itunes:summary: This episode discusses Statement Six of the Women for Sobriety program, Life can be ordinary or it can be great.  How do we find the greatness already existing in our lives?

item.title: Statement Five: 4C-ing a Positive Outlook
item.description: This episode discusses WFS Statement Five, which forms the backbone of the program. From it we get the 4C's, that we are Capable, Competent, Caring and Compassionate.
item.dc:creator: M. Broughton Boone
item.itunes:summary: This episode discusses WFS Statement Five, which forms the backbone of the program. From it we get the 4C's, that we are Capable, Competent, Caring and Compassionate.

item.title: Statement Four: Are You Bothered?
item.description: This episode discusses WFS Statement Four, which reads: Problems bother me only to the degree I permit them to.  I now better understand my problems and do not permit problems to overwhelm me.
item.dc:creator: M. Broughton Boone
item.itunes:summary: This episode discusses WFS Statement Four, which reads: Problems bother me only to the degree I permit them to.  I now better understand my problems and do not permit problems to overwhelm me.

item.title: Statement Three: If You're Happy and You Know It
item.description: The third affirmation statement of Women for Sobriety reads, Happiness is a habit I will develop. Happiness is created, not waited for. This week we discuss finding happiness in early sobriety.
item.dc:creator: M. Broughton Boone
item.itunes:summary: The third affirmation statement of Women for Sobriety reads, Happiness is a habit I will develop. Happiness is created, not waited for. This week we discuss finding happiness in early sobriety.

item.title: Statement Two: Finding the Positive
item.description: This episode discusses the second statement of the Women for Sobriety, Inc. program. This statement says, "Negative thoughts destroy only myself."
item.dc:creator: M. Broughton Boone
item.itunes:summary: This episode discusses the second statement of the Women for Sobriety, Inc. program. This statement says, "Negative thoughts destroy only myself."

item.title: Statement One: The Key to Sobriety
item.description: The first in a series of talks about the Thirteen Affirmation Statements of Women for Sobriety, Inc. This podcast discusses the first Statement, "I have a life-threatening problem that once had me."
item.dc:creator: M. Broughton Boone
item.itunes:summary: The first in a series of talks about the Thirteen Affirmation Statements of Women for Sobriety, Inc. This podcast discusses the first Statement, "I have a life-threatening problem that once had me."
